perturbation.original_text: Each purchase order shall set forth a delivery date for the quantities of Product ordered, which date will in no event be less than *** from the date of the purchase order. MacroGenics will use Commercially Reasonable Efforts to deliver each order on or before the applicable deliver date.
perturbation.changed_text: Each purchase order shall set forth a delivery date for the quantities of Product ordered, which date will in no event be less than *2 days* from the date of the purchase order. MacroGenics will use Commercially Reasonable Efforts to deliver each order on or before the applicable deliver date.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the delivery timeframe to 2 days is likely not commercially reasonable given manufacturing and shipping constraints, potentially conflicting with obligations to use commercially reasonable efforts. This could violate general contract law principles requiring good faith and reasonableness.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - commercially reasonable efforts

perturbation.original_text:
The reviewing Party shall have the right (a) to propose modifications to the publication or presentation for patent reasons, trade secret reasons, or for purposes of removing the Confidential Information of the reviewing Party, or (b) to request a reasonable delay in publication or submission for presentation in order to protect trade secret or patentable information.

(ii) If the reviewing Party requests the removal of the reviewing Party's Confidential Information or a delay, the publishing Party shall remove such Confidential Information and delay submission for publication or submission for presentation for a period of *** to enable patent applications protecting each Party's rights in such Confidential Information to be filed in accordance with Section 15 below.
perturbation.changed_text:
The reviewing Party shall have the right (a) to propose modifications to the publication or presentation for patent reasons, trade secret reasons, or for purposes of removing the Confidential Information of the reviewing Party, or (b) to request a reasonable delay in publication or submission for presentation in order to protect trade secret or patentable information.

(ii) If the reviewing Party requests the removal of the reviewing Party's Confidential Information or a delay, the publishing Party shall remove such Confidential Information and delay submission for publication or submission for presentation for a period of *3 days* to enable patent applications protecting each Party's rights in such Confidential Information to be filed in accordance with Section 15 below.
perturbation.explanation: Delaying submission for only 3 days is insufficient for preparing and filing patent applications, conflicting with legal requirements and best practices for protecting intellectual property. In most jurisdictions, preparing and filing a patent application takes significantly longer than 3 days.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Patent Law - insufficient time to file patent application

perturbation.original_text: Each Party shall notify the other in writing of any allegations it receives from a Third Party that the manufacture, production, use, development, sale or distribution of any Product or any technology or intellectual property licensed by a Party under this Agreement infringes the intellectual property rights of such Third Party. Such notice shall be provided promptly, but in no event after more than fifteen (15) business days, following receipt of such allegations.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party shall notify the other in writing of any allegations it receives from a Third Party that the manufacture, production, use, development, sale or distribution of any Product or any technology or intellectual property licensed by a Party under this Agreement infringes the intellectual property rights of such Third Party. Such notice shall be provided *only when deemed necessary* by the notifying party.
perturbation.explanation: Delaying or omitting infringement notices could cause the other party to lose rights or remedies, violating duties of good faith and fair dealing, and creating liability under intellectual property law for failure to mitigate damages or address infringement issues promptly.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Intellectual Property Law - duty to mitigate damages and address infringement; General Contract Law - good faith and fair dealing
